HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 16, 1924

A SUGGESTION FOR THE CURRICULUM
At a number of the leading colleges and universities in the East
there is offered a course for Freshmen intended to make the new men
familiar with the college. The authorities of the various institutions were aware of the great change in methods and customs of college life from that of the preparatory school, and hence they conceived the idea of a course in "orientation". The one now in operation at New York University, known there as a " Birdseye" Course
was modeled, to a certain extent, after one in use at Brown University, and at both institutions the course has met with a marked de-

A new graduate school has
been proposed for Hopkins: a
School of International Relations.
It was planned by a group of men
who are deeply interested in international welfare, who believe
that an intelligent approach
through specialized study by students at a university of high
standing is one of the ways to get
leaders for the affairs of the future.
Two reasons are given for the
consideration of Hopkins before
any other school. First, it is proposed to establish the school as a
memorial to Walter Hines Page,
world famous diplomat and author, former ambassador to England. Mr. Page was a graduate of
Hopkins, so it was thought by the
committee that his Alma Mater
was the proper place to establish
the new school.
Second, Hopkins has long
maintained a high standard,' one
of the highest in the world, in its
work in the field of international
relations. Such men as Willoughby, Goodnow and Latane,
with their students, have long
lead in this branch of graduate
study. This was the determining
factor in picking Hopkins.
it is not at all sure that the
school will be established as yet.
A committee to confer with President Goodnow, and to raise the
81,000,000 endowment fund has
been appointed. Former Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Franklin D. Roosevelt, is chairman of
the endowment committee.

The whole plan is as yet nebulous. The course will consist,
probably, of two years graduate
work at Johns Hopkins, with an
additional year of travel and personal contact with foreign peogree of success.

of other lands.

Dr. H. Carrington Lancaster,
Professor of French at Johns Hopkins, sails next September to begin a year's term as director of
the American University Union
in Paris. Professor Lancaster will
succeed Algernon Coleman, of the
University of Chicago. Dr. Coleman is an alumnus of Johns Hopkins.
American
The
University
Union is a connecting link between intellectual Europe and
America. It was organized in
1917 by a group of American colleges as a club for their alumni
overseas. It has officers in New
York, London and Paris and is
invaluable in aiding American
students. By applying to the
Union, American students in Europe are permitted to use otherwise inaccessible private collections; they are introduced to specialists, whom they could not
otherwise meet; they are given
lists of the best universities, and,
in general, are aided in many
ways.
Last year there were over three
thousand American students in
Paris, 429 of whom were enrolled
at the University of Paris.
On the other hand the Union
also helps to familiarize France
with the American system of education.
Professor C. M. Gayley, of the
University of Southern California
is expected to be the Director of
the British Division.
The Union is now controlled by
a committee of the American
Council on Education. Its Paris
address is 173 Boulevard SaintGermain, and its London office is
50 Russell Square.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 16, 1924

A SUGGESTION FOR THE CURRICULUM
At a number of the leading colleges and universities in the East
there is offered a course for Freshmen intended to make the new men
familiar with the college. The authorities of the various institutions were aware of the great change in methods and customs of college life from that of the preparatory school, and hence they conceived the idea of a course in "orientation". The one now in operation at New York University, known there as a " Birdseye" Course
was modeled, to a certain extent, after one in use at Brown University, and at both institutions the course has met with a marked de-

A new graduate school has
been proposed for Hopkins: a
School of International Relations.
It was planned by a group of men
who are deeply interested in international welfare, who believe
that an intelligent approach
through specialized study by students at a university of high
standing is one of the ways to get
leaders for the affairs of the future.
Two reasons are given for the
consideration of Hopkins before
any other school. First, it is proposed to establish the school as a
memorial to Walter Hines Page,
world famous diplomat and author, former ambassador to England. Mr. Page was a graduate of
Hopkins, so it was thought by the
committee that his Alma Mater
was the proper place to establish
the new school.
Second, Hopkins has long
maintained a high standard,' one
of the highest in the world, in its
work in the field of international
relations. Such men as Willoughby, Goodnow and Latane,
with their students, have long
lead in this branch of graduate
study. This was the determining
factor in picking Hopkins.
it is not at all sure that the
school will be established as yet.
A committee to confer with President Goodnow, and to raise the
81,000,000 endowment fund has
been appointed. Former Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Franklin D. Roosevelt, is chairman of
the endowment committee.

The whole plan is as yet nebulous. The course will consist,
probably, of two years graduate
work at Johns Hopkins, with an
additional year of travel and personal contact with foreign peogree of success.

of other lands.

Dr. H. Carrington Lancaster,
Professor of French at Johns Hopkins, sails next September to begin a year's term as director of
the American University Union
in Paris. Professor Lancaster will
succeed Algernon Coleman, of the
University of Chicago. Dr. Coleman is an alumnus of Johns Hopkins.
American
The
University
Union is a connecting link between intellectual Europe and
America. It was organized in
1917 by a group of American colleges as a club for their alumni
overseas. It has officers in New
York, London and Paris and is
invaluable in aiding American
students. By applying to the
Union, American students in Europe are permitted to use otherwise inaccessible private collections; they are introduced to specialists, whom they could not
otherwise meet; they are given
lists of the best universities, and,
in general, are aided in many
ways.
Last year there were over three
thousand American students in
Paris, 429 of whom were enrolled
at the University of Paris.
On the other hand the Union
also helps to familiarize France
with the American system of education.
Professor C. M. Gayley, of the
University of Southern California
is expected to be the Director of
the British Division.
The Union is now controlled by
a committee of the American
Council on Education. Its Paris
address is 173 Boulevard SaintGermain, and its London office is
50 Russell Square.
